ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Study of Na substitution in La0.67Ba0.33MnO3 perovskites

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Laboratoire des Matériaux et du Génie Physique, Grenoble INP, CNRS (UMR 5628)
Laboratoire de Physico-chimie des Matériaux, Département de Physique, Faculté des Sciences de Monastir, 5019

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
The effect of Na substitution on nominal La0.67Ba0.33−x Na x MnO3 (0≤x≤0.33) manganites is studied in this work. Detailed chemical and structural analyses on ceramic samples obtained at 1200 ∘C show that a significantly lower Na rate than the nominal one is obtained due to important Na losses during the synthesis. The losses of Na result in the appearance of impurity phases for high nominal Na rates in addition to the manganite phase with a rhombohedral
$R\bar{3}c$ structure. Structural and physical properties of the samples can be properly interpreted according to the variation of the Mn3+/Mn4+ ratio and the average ionic radius of A-site when the experimental composition of the manganite is considered.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
The hole doped perovskites, Ln1−x A x MnO3 (Ln=rare earth, A=Ca, Sr, Ba, etc.) have been extensively studied due to their colossal magnetoresistance (CMR) properties. These CMR properties depend strongly on the synthesis conditions, the doping level in the A-site, the average ionic radius of A-site, the deficiency of oxygen, etc. (see [1] for a review). For this reason, a complete analysis is needed to properly interpret these mixed-valence state systems. Along this line, we have studied in this paper the effect of Ba substitution by Na on La0.67Ba0.33MnO3. Indeed the properties of this manganite can be tuned by an appropriate substitution of the divalent cation Ba2+ by a monovalent cation such as Na+. In relation with this work, magnetocaloric properties of nominal La0.7Ba0.3−z Na z MnO3 (z=0.05, 0.1, and 0.15) manganites have been previously studied [2]. However, only nominal compositions of the manganite phase were considered in [2] without taking into account any shift in composition with respect to nominal one. This shift is highly expected from very important Na losses at the relatively high temperature used for the synthesis (10 h at 1000 ∘C in [2]) and was previously reported by several authors in Na substituted manganites (incorporation efficiencies of Na, x Na,real/x Na,nom, ranging from 0.35 to 0.80 are reported for La0.7Ca0.3−x Na x MnO3±δ system [3] and ranging from 0.72<x real/x nom<0.76 for La1−x Na x MnO3±δ system [4]). In addition, the X-ray diffraction pattern of their materials, claimed to be a single rhombohedral phase (with
$R\bar{3}c$ space group), contains extra peaks (e.g., near 29∘ in the XRD pattern of Fig. 1-a of [2]) of a non-identified secondary phase showing no correspondence to rhombohedral diffraction lines (vertical lines in their figure). The appearance of impurity phases in [2] is indeed a clear indication of these Na losses and of the subsequent shift in composition with respect to nominal one. Due to the lack of information about real composition in these previous studies (see also [5]), we are interested in our work to determine accurately the chemical composition of the Na substituted manganites with nominal formula La0.67Ba0.33−x Na x MnO3 (0≤x≤0.33). The chemical composition is used to interpret the properties of these manganites. In particular, we present their structural and physical properties as a function of the Mn3+/Mn4+ ratio derived from the chemical composition. This dependence of the properties appears fully coherent in terms of double exchange (DE) interaction available from the literature [1, and references therein], which depends directly on the Mn3+/Mn4+ ratio.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para: Ceramic samples with La0.67Ba0.33−x Na x MnO3 nominal compositions were prepared by standard solid state reaction using stoeichiometric amounts of La2O3, BaCO3, Na2O3, and MnO2 precursors all with purity better than 99.9 %. Care was taken to remove moisture before weighing by preheating the precursors at 600 ∘C for 12 h. The mixtures were heated in air at 800 ∘C for 72 h to achieve decarbonization. After grinding, they were heated at 1000 ∘C for 24 h and ground again to ensure homogeneity. Finally, the powders were several times pressed into pellets and sintered at 1200 ∘C for 24 h in air with intermediate grinding and repelleting. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected in the 2θ range 10∘–100∘ with a step size of 0.017° and a counting time of 18 s per step using a “PANalytical X’Pert Pro” diffractometer with filtered (Ni filter) Cu radiation. Standard Si powder was used to obtain the instrumental resolution function. A structure refinement was carried out by the Rietveld [6] analysis. Microstructure, phase identification and preliminary composition analysis of the samples were studied by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) using a Philips XL30 microscope with an energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrometer. Quantitative analyses of the chemical elements, including the oxygen, were performed by the inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICPAES) technique. Magnetization measurements were performed using extraction magnetometry. The magnetization as a function of the temperature, M(T), in the range 10–500 K was measured under a constant magnetic field (0.05 T). The field dependence of the magnetization, M(H), was measured at 50 K with variable field H up to 100 kOe. The temperature dependence of the electrical resistivity, ρ(T), was measured in the temperature range 80–300 K, using electrical contacts on disk shape ceramic samples with a diameter of 10 mm and a thickness of about 2 mm.

Section2.Heading: Morphological analysis, chemical composition, and phase identification of the manganites
Section2.Para:
SEM, EDX and XRD analyses on samples with nominal composition La0.67Ba0.33−x Na x MnO3 (0≤x≤0.33) indicate the presence of a manganite as a major phase and the appearance of two minor impurity phases identified as Hausmannite (Mn3O4) and Birnessite (Na0.55Mn2O4⋅1.5H2O). In particular, back-scattered electrons SEM micrographs show that below x≤0.05 nominal composition, the samples exhibit a uniform contrast corresponding to a single phase manganite (e.g., x=0 in Fig. 1-a) whereas for x=0.1,0.15,0.2, and 0.25 nominal compositions the samples show a coexistence of two phases: a major manganite phase with an homogeneous white contrast and a minor impurity phase with a dark contrast identified as an Hausmannite impurity phase. Finally, for x=0.33 Na nominal content (see Fig. 1-b), an additional impurity phase can be identified as a Birnessite phase. In agreement with SEM results, no impurities were observed in the XRD patterns below x≤0.05 nominal Na content and only sharp and intense Bragg peaks corresponding to the manganite phase are present (see Fig. 2). Above that, nominal Na concentration impurities are observed: an additional small peak at 2θ=36∘ (indicated by an asterisk with red color in Fig. 2) corresponds to an Hausmannite impurity phase (Mn3O4), whereas two further additional peaks at 2θ=12.3∘ and 24.9∘ (marked by asterisk with blue color in Fig. 2 for x=0.33) correspond to a Birnessite [7, 8] impurity phase (Na0.55Mn2O4⋅1.5H2O).
Fig. 1
SEM images (back-scattered electron mode) of samples with La0.67Ba0.33−x Na x MnO3 (x=0 and 0.33) nominal composition. Undoped sample exhibits a unique contrast corresponding to the manganite phase whereas for x=0.33 two minor impurities are identified as a Hausmannite phase (Mn3O4) and a Birnessite phase (Na0.55Mn2O4⋅1.5H2O)
Fig. 2
XRD patterns for samples with La0.67Ba0.33−x Na x MnO3 (x=0, 0.05, 0.2, and 0.33) nominal composition. All peaks of the manganite phase are indexed in the hexagonal setting of the rhombohedral
$R\bar{3}c$ symmetry. Extra peaks from secondary phases (x=0.2 and 0.33) are marked by asterisks (red colour for Hausmannite (Mn3O4) and blue color for Birnessite (Na0.55Mn2O4⋅1.5H2O)). Inset: Rietveld analysis results for x=0.2 sample. Observed (Yobs) and calculated (Ycalc) patterns are compared (blue line). The vertical ticks show the positions of the calculated Bragg reflections for the major rhombohedral manganite phase (top
$R\bar{3}c$ space group) and the minor Mn3O4 phase (bottom I41/amd space group)

The above mentioned presence of impurity phases in the samples is a clear indication of a departure from the nominal chemical composition. Moreover, EDX qualitative analyses on the manganite phase show a lower Na content than the nominal one. Further information on chemical composition obtained by ICPAES (Table 1) indicate that the sample’s atomic composition of La, Ba, and Mn (within the uncertainties of ICPAES analysis) is close to the nominal one, whereas Na and O contents are significantly lower than the nominal values. The Na deficiency can be related to a loss of Na due to its appreciable sublimation at high temperature during the synthesis [3, 4, 9, 10]. The deficiency of O results from the formation of Hausmannite and Birnessite impurity phases as is exemplified as follows. Indeed, the chemical compositions of the manganite phases (Table 2) can be obtained from the overall samples compositions obtained by ICPAES considering the amounts of the impurity phases (estimated by a quantitative phase (Rietveld) analysis using XRD and summarized in Table 2). As an example, for the sample with x=0.2, the XRD quantitative phase analysis indicates an amount of nearly 2.5 % of Mn3O4 (in at. %) as the unique impurity phase for this nominal composition. Thus, the composition given in Table 1 corresponds to a mixture of two phases and can be rewritten as
$$\begin{aligned} &0.975\times \mathrm{La}_{\alpha}\mathrm{Ba}_{\beta}\mathrm{Na}_{x'}\mathrm{MnO}_{\lambda} +0.025\times \mathrm{Mn}_{3}\mathrm{O}_{4} \\ &\quad = A\times \mathrm{La}_{0.67(2)}\mathrm{Ba}_{0.12(2)}\mathrm{Na}_{0.069(2)}\mathrm{Mn}_{1.00(2)} \mathrm{O}_{2.5(2)} \end{aligned}$$ where A is a renormalization factor. Thus, considering each chemical species, we have: a
$$\begin{aligned} &\mbox{La}\quad 0.975\alpha = A\times 0.67(2) \end{aligned}$$
b
$$\begin{aligned} &\mbox{Ba}\quad 0.975\beta= A\times 0.12(2) \end{aligned}$$
c
$$\begin{aligned} &\mbox{Na} \quad 0.975x' = A\times 0.069(2) \end{aligned}$$
d
$$\begin{aligned} &\mbox{Mn} \quad 0.975+ 0.025\times 3 = A\times 1.00(2) \end{aligned}$$
e
$$\begin{aligned} &\mbox{O} \quad 0.975 \lambda+ 0.025\times 4 = A\times 2.5(2) \end{aligned}$$ Equation (d) gives: A=1.05(2).

The A value reported in Eqs. (a), (b), (c), and (e) gives α=0.71(3), β=0.13(2), x′=0.074(2), and λ=2.8(2), which corresponds within the error bars to the values in the last column of Table 2.

The results of Table 2 show that our nominal composition of Na is not reached due to the easy sublimation of Na at high temperature [9, 10] and only a maximum value equal to 0.15 for x=0.33 Na nominal content is obtained representing an efficiency of Na incorporation of 45 % that is comparable to the value reported in the literature for similar synthesis conditions (e.g., 0.35<x real/x nom<0.80 for La0.7Ca0.3−x Na x MnO3±δ system [3] and 0.72<x real/x nom<0.76 for La x Na1−x MnO3±δ system [4]). A rapid estimation of the maximum value equal to 0.15 for x=0.33 Na nominal content can be obtained by comparing the dependence of the a cell parameters (in hexagonal setting) of the manganite phase present in our samples as a function of their nominal compositions (black squares in Fig. 3) against the dependence of the a cell parameter (in hexagonal setting) as a function of measured compositions in the La1−x Na x MnO3±δ system whose limits are represented by dashed lines in Fig. 3 (see details in Fig. 4 of the next section). From this comparison, it appears that the possible Na compositions corresponding to a magnitude of 5.4902 Å (a cell parameter of sample with x=0.33 Na nominal content) range roughly from 0.125 to 0.2 in good agreement with the composition in Table 2 (0.15). The dependence of the a cell parameter of our samples as a function of compositions deduced in Table 2 (light grey squares in Fig. 3) is almost linear in contrast with the dependence against nominal values that shows a discontinuity (dot lines) near 0.15 coinciding with the presence of Hausmannite-type impurity. We have represented in the same figure by open squares the dependence of the a cell parameters of samples found in the literature [2, 5, 11–14] as a function of their nominal compositions. A close comparison with our data shows that 0.1, 0.15, and 0.33 samples [2, 5] have the wrong Na content as is the case for most of our samples when considering their nominal compositions. We finally note that the composition of the manganite (La0.73Na0.15MnO3) exhibits an enrichment in La content with respect to Mn content, reaching a La/Mn ratio equal to 0.73, instead of 0.67 for x=0.33 Na nominal content. This increase in the La/Mn ratio is directly related to the Na losses. In principle, the Na deficiency will result in a lacunars manganite, but only the creation of a small quantities of vacancies in the A site is possible leading to the formation of the two (Mn rich) minor impurity phases. The small amount of vacancies in the A-site reported in Table 2 is in good agreement with [15–18] and reaches a maximum value of about 0.12 for La0.73Na0.15MnO3 manganite (see penultimate column in Table 2). Hereafter, only the manganite formula corresponding to the last column of Table 2 will be used unless specified.
Fig. 3
Dependence of the a cell parameter (in hexagonal setting) of the manganite phase as a function of the nominal Na content in our work (black squares) and in the literature (open squares) as compared with that in the La1−x Na x MnO3±δ system as a function of measured compositions (delimited by red dashed lines). The dependence against real Na content in our samples is represented by light grey squares. Vertical lines indicate the expected Na compositions for sample with x=0.33 Na nominal content
Fig. 4
Dependence of the a (squares) and c (circles) cell parameters (in hexagonal setting) of the manganite phase as a function of the real Na content in our work (grey symbols) and compared to that reported in the literature for La1−x Na x MnO3±δ (red symbols delimited by red dashed lines) and La0.7Ca0.3−x Na x MnO3±δ (green symbols). Zone of coincidence (see text) for our system and La1−x Na x MnO3±δ system is highlighted by red ellipses. Hypothetical zone of coincidence (see text) for La0.7Ca0.3−x Na x MnO3±δ system and La1−x Na x MnO3±δ system is highlighted by green ellipses

Section2.Heading: Structural properties
Section2.Para:
XRD Rietveld refinement revealed that all the samples exhibit a rhombohedral (
$R \bar{3}c$ , n∘167) manganite phase. The atomic positions are taken at 6a (0,0,1/4) for (La/Ba/Na), 6b (0,0,0) for Mn, and 18e (x,0,1/4) for O. The inset of Fig. 2 exemplifies the Rietveld refinement for the manganite with La0.68Ba0.13Na0.072MnO3 composition (present in the sample with x=0.2 Na nominal content) showing a good agreement between observed and calculated profiles. Detailed results of the refinement are listed in Table 3 and represented in Figs. 4 and 5. The a and c cell parameters (and thus the unit cell volume) decrease monotonically with increasing Na content (see light grey symbol in Fig. 4). These decreases in the lattice constants can be related on the one side to the difference of ionic radii of the La3+ and Na+ with respect to the Ba2+ ions (
$r_{\mathrm{La}^{3+}} = 1.36$ Å,
$r_{(\mathrm{Na}^{+})} = 1.39$ Å and
$r_{(\mathrm{Ba}^{2+})} = 1.61$ Å [19]) and on the other side to the formation of a larger proportion of Mn4+ with respect to Mn3+ ion with different radii (
$r_{\mathrm{Mn}^{3+}} = 0.645$ Å and
$r_{\mathrm{Mn}^{4+}} = 0.53$ Å).
Fig. 5

Table 3 and Fig. 5 show also that the Mn-O-Mn bond angle (δ Mn-O-Mn) and the Mn-O bond length (d Mn-O) change systematically with varying the Goldschmidt tolerance factor [20]: 1
$$ t_G = \bigl(\langle r_A \rangle + r_O\bigr)/\sqrt{2}\bigl(\langle r_B \rangle + r_O\bigr) $$ where 〈r
A 〉, 〈r
B 〉, and r
O are, respectively, the average ionic radii of A, B, and O perovskites sites.

These structural parameters show also that the sample La0.69Ba0.29Na0.018MnO2.94 has a different behavior (it has the lowest values for the position x O of the oxygen and the bond length d Mn-O and the highest value of δ Mn-O-Mn); this behavior can be related to the deficiency of O in this compound (see Fig. 5 and Tables 2 and 3) [1, and references therein, 3, 15].

Table 4 included structural parameters of the La1−x Na x MnO3±δ [4, 16, 17, 21–23] and La0.7Ca0.3−x Na x MnO3±δ [3] systems for further relevant comparison. We note that in these works the authors have performed an extensive chemical and structural analysis of their samples. In particular, [4, 16, 17, 21–23] showed that their final Na compositions are lower than the nominal one due to sublimation with similar incorporation rates than in our samples.

Figure 4 compares the dependence of the a and c cell parameters of the data reported in Table 4 as a function of the Na compositions for the La1−x Na x MnO3±δ system (red), the La0.7Ca0.3−x Na x MnO3±δ system (green), and our samples (grey). Despite the large amount of dataset used in Table 4 for the La1−x Na x MnO3±δ system, only a small spread of the data is observed in Fig. 4. The spread is mainly due to the different techniques used in each reference as can be seen in Fig. 4 by half-filled symbols used for [4] and [21, 22] corresponding to samples with similar compositions. The boundaries of the region including all the datasets are represented by red dashed lines in Fig. 4 for the La1−x Na x MnO3±δ system.

As can be seen from Table 4, our structural parameters for the last sample coincide with those of samples of the La1−x Na x MnO3±δ system near the x′=0.15 Na at. % [4, 16, 17, 21–23], and thus confirm our results. This coincidence region is highlighted in Fig. 4 by red ellipses.

Figure 4 shows a different behavior for the La1−x Na x MnO3±δ system, the La0.7Ca0.3−x Na x MnO3±δ system, and our samples. Almost no dependence is observed for the La0.7Ca0.3−x Na x MnO3±δ system [3]. Solid green lines correspond to extrapolated values for hypothetical higher Na content. As expected, the coincidence region with the La1−x Na x MnO3±δ system takes place for 0.33 Na content as highlighted in Fig. 4 by green ellipses. The absence of dependence shown in Fig. 4 for La0.7Ca0.3−x Na x MnO3±δ system is expected as only a slight decrease is expected from difference in the substituted cations (a slight increase results when Ca2+ (
$r_{\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}} = 1.34$ Å) is replaced by Na+ (
$r_{\mathrm{Na}^{+}} = 1.39$ Å) whereas a larger, but small, decrease results from replacement of Mn3+ (
$r_{\mathrm{Mn}^{3+}} = 0.645$ Å) by Mn4+ (
$r_{\mathrm{Mn}^{4+}} = 0.53$ Å). A similar situation arises in the La1−x Na x MnO3±δ system and the larger decreasing observed for the a parameter (c parameter is almost constant) is essentially due to the fact that each Na+ leads to two Mn4+ (only a slight increase results when La3+ (
$r_{\mathrm{La}^{3+}} = 1.36$ Å) is replaced by Na+ (
$r_{\mathrm{Na}^{+}} = 1.39$ Å). Finally, our system presents the larger decrease of both a and c parameter that arises when (
$r_{\mathrm{Ba}^{2+}} = 1.61$ Å) is replaced by either Na+ (
$r_{\mathrm{Na}^{+}} = 1.39$ Å) or (
$r_{\mathrm{La}^{3+}} = 1.36$ Å) and Mn3+ (
$r_{\mathrm{Mn}^{3+}} = 0.645$ Å) is replaced by Mn4+ (
$r_{\mathrm{Mn}^{4+}} = 0.53$ Å). Similarly, the values observed for the cell parameters (larger for our system and smaller for La0.7Ca0.3−x Na x MnO3±δ ) can directly relate to cation sizes.

The small amount of vacancies in the A-site reported in our system is in good agreement with (see third column in Table 4) values reported in the La0.7Ca0.3−x Na x MnO3±δ and La1−x Na x MnO3±δ systems.

Section2.Heading: Magnetic properties
Section2.Para:
Figure 6 shows M(T) curves for samples with Na content x′=0, 0.018, 0.072, and 0.15, in at. %. A clear paramagnetic (PM)-ferromagnetic (FM) phase transition, corresponding to the sharp increase of M(T), is observed in this figure. An estimation of the Curie temperature T
C can be obtained in the paramagnetic region (above T
C ) by a linear fit of the Curie–Weiss law: 2
$$ 1/\chi= (T -T_{C})/C $$ (see the inset (a) in Fig. 6), where T
C is the Curie–Weiss temperature and C is the Curie constant defined as 3
$$ C= (1/ 3 k_B)(N_a/M_m)\bigl(\mu^{\mathrm{meas}}_{\mathrm{eff}}\bigr)^2 \mu^2_B $$
k
B the Boltzmann constant and
$\mu_{\mathrm{eff}}^{\mathrm{meas}}$ the measured effective moment expressed in Bohr magneton. The variation of T
C with x′ (see Table 5 and Fig. 7) is similar to the one of the Mn3+ concentration. This variation is also related to the bandwidth, W, given by the empirical formula: 4
$$ W \approx \cos (\theta/2)/d_{\text{Mn-O}^{3.5}} $$ where θ=180∘−δ Mn-O-Mn is the tilt angle in the Mn-O-Mn plane [1]. The Na losses at high temperature during the synthesis lead only to a relative small increase of Na content in the samples and as a consequence only a slight change in T
C values is observed with Na doping. Similarly to our results, the T
C values in [2] diminish only by 5 K when their Na nominal content reaches 0.15. As the change in T
C is comparable to our results, it appears that the real chemical composition of samples in [2] should be much lower than the nominal values. Beyond x′=0.046 Na content, magnetization curves exhibit a slight increase near 46 K (see by example x′=0.072 and 0.15 (Na at. %) in Fig. 6) due to the contribution of the ferromagnetic Mn3O4 secondary phase whose transition temperature is 46 K [24].

The (b) inset shows the field dependence of the magnetization measured at T=50 K for samples with Na content (x′=0, 0.018, 0.072, and 0.15, in at. %)

The calculated effective moment can be compared with the measured one using the following formula: 5
$$ \mu^{\mathrm{th}}_{\mathrm{eff}}(\mu_B) = \sqrt{c_{\mathrm{Mn}^{3+}}\bigl[\mu^{\mathrm{th}}_{\mathrm{eff}} \bigl(\mathrm{Mn}^{3+}\bigr) \bigr]^2 + c_{\mathrm{Mn}^{4+}}\bigl[ \mu^{\mathrm{th}}_{\mathrm{eff}}\bigl(\mathrm{Mn}^{4+}\bigr) \bigr]^2 } $$ where
$c_{\mathrm{Mn}^{3+}}$ and
$c_{\mathrm{Mn}^{4+}}$ are the Mn3+ and Mn4+ concentrations deduced from the manganite formulas,
$\mu^{\mathrm{th}}_{\mathrm{eff}} (\mathrm{Mn}^{3+}) \approx 4.90\mu_{B}$ and
$\mu^{\mathrm{th}}_{\mathrm{eff}} (\mathrm{Mn}^{4+}) \approx 3.87\mu_{B}$ . As if often the case for manganites, one finds that the measured effective magnetic moments in the PM regime are significantly larger than the calculated ones (see Table 5). This may be due to short range FM correlation in the PM state [25].

The corresponding M(H) curves (the (b) inset of Fig. 6) shows a typical FM regime with a sharp increase of the magnetization at low field corresponding to rearrangement of FM domains. This magnetization reaches rapidly an almost constant value for higher fields corresponding to parallel alignment of the spins.

The measured saturation moment
$\mu_{s}^{\mathrm{meas}}$ (see Table 5) corresponds to the value of magnetization at the highest value of magnetic field (10 T). Table 5 compares
$\mu_{s}^{\mathrm{meas}}$ with the theoretical moment
$\mu_{s}^{\mathrm{cal}}$ calculated
$\mu_{s}^{\mathrm{cal}} (\mu_{B}/f.u.)= 2\mu_{B}[c_{\mathrm{Mn}^{3+}}\times \frac{4}{2}+c_{\mathrm{Mn}^{4+}}\times \frac{3}{2}]$ , the
$\mu_{s}^{\mathrm{cal}}$ values have been obtained assuming a quenched orbital moment, with spin moment, S=2 for Mn3+, S=3/2 for Mn4+ and g=2 for both Mn3+ and Mn4+. for a full spin alignment in the limit of T=0 K. As expected for a ferromagnetic manganite, the observed and calculated magnetic saturation moments coincide reasonably when we used the
$c_{\mathrm{Mn}^{4+}}/c_{\mathrm{Mn}^{3+}}$ ratio given by the real manganite formula (last column in Table 2), which confirms that a FM state is present in our samples.

Section2.Heading: Electrical properties
Section2.Para:
ρ(T) curves for samples with Na content x′=0, 0.018, 0.116, and 0.15 (in at. %) are shown in Fig. 8. All the samples, except the one with x′=0.018, exhibit a transition from a metallic behavior (below T
P ) to an insulator behavior (above T
P ) at the peak temperature T
P . The maximum value of the resistivity
$\rho_{T_{P}}$ and the temperature transition T
P values are listed in Table 6. As x′ increases, we observed an increase in
$\rho_{T_{P}}$ values, which appears low for samples with 0≤x′≤0.116, and high for x′=0.15. This variation in the
$\rho_{T_{P}}$ maximum resistivity can be related to the bandwidth, W (see Table 3). This is consistent (while ignoring the one with x′=0.018) with the decrease of the peak temperature T
P from 268 K for x′=0 to 240 K for x′=0.046, whereas between x′=0.046 and 0.116, T
P increases from 240 K to 255 K, then decreases again to 238 K for x′=0.15. One can notice that our T
P value for x′=0.15 (x=0.33) Na content is in good agreement with the one reported in [5] for La0.67Na0.33MnO3 (LNMO) compound (T
P =247 K).This shows that the real chemical composition of sample in [5] should be much lower than the nominal value.

We noted also that the T
P values of our specimens are lower than T
C values (see Tables 5 and 6); such difference is often attributed to the grain boundaries effects [26]. Other studies suggest that the doping level in the A-site [4] as well as oxygen deficiency [27] play an important role for the observed electrical behavior.

In order to understand the transport properties in the whole temperature range, especially around the peak temperature (T
P ), a phenomenological model based on the phase segregation mechanism was developed [28–30]. Following this model, we carried out a quantitative analysis of the resistivity temperature dependence data for samples with different Na compositions (0≤x′≤0.15). According to [28–30], the resistivity is formulated as 6
$$ \rho(T ) = \rho_{\mathrm{FM}} (T)f +\rho_{\mathrm{PM}} (T)f' $$ where f is the volume concentration of ferromagnetic (FM) phase, f′=1−f is the volume concentration of PM phase. The volume concentrations of FM and PM phases satisfy the Boltzmann distribution: 7
$$ f= \frac{1}{1+\exp (\frac{\Delta U}{k_B T})} $$ where 8
$$ \Delta U \approx -U _0 \biggl(1- \frac{T}{T_C^{\mathrm{mod}}}\biggr) $$ ΔU is the energy difference between FM and PM states and
$T^{\mathrm{mod}}_{C}$ means a temperature in the vicinity of what the resistivity has a maximum value.

From Eqs. (7) and (8), one can find that
$$\begin{aligned} &f = 0\quad \mbox{for}\ T\gg T_C^{\mathrm{mod}},\quad f= 1\ \mbox{for} T\ll T_C^{\mathrm{mod}} \quad \mbox{and} \\ &f = f_{c} = 1/2\quad \mbox{at}\ T= T_C^{\mathrm{mod}} \end{aligned} $$ where f
c is the percolation threshold.

To conclude, when f<f
c the sample remains an insulator, whereas if f>f
c it becomes metallic. Then a complete expression describing the resistivity dependence in the whole temperature range as a function of temperature is of the form:
where ρ 0 is the resistivity due to grain/domain boundaries and point defects scattering [31], ρ 2 T 2 represents the electrical resistivity due to the electron-electron process [32], ρ 4.5 T 4.5 is caused by the electron-magnon scattering processes [33], and E
a the activation energy and D is a coefficient independent of T.

Equation (6)′ has been fitted to our experimental data at any temperature between 80 K and 300 K. An excellent agreement between the calculated (red solid line) and the experimental data is clearly seen in Fig. 8. The goodness of fit is usually evaluated by comparing the squared coefficient of linear correlation coefficient (χ 2) (see Table 6). As can be seen in Table 6, the values of the parameters ρ 0, ρ 2, ρ 4.5, E
a and U 0 vary systematically with varying the average ionic radius of A-site, 〈r
A 〉 [33]. These parameters increase with decreasing (respectively decrease with increasing) 〈r
A 〉, according to the reduction (respectively the increase) of DE coupling (DEC). In particular, our parameters for the sample with x′=0.15 (Na at. %) (ρ 0=0.096 Ωm, ρ 2=3.993×10−7 Ωm K−2, ρ 4.5=3.851×10−12 Ωm K−4.5 and E
a =149.33 meV) are higher with the one reported in [5] for La0.67Na0.33MnO3 compound (ρ 0=5.8653 Ωcm, ρ 2=0.00140 Ωcm K−2, ρ 4.5=5.94×10−11 Ωcm K−4.5, and E
a =66.2 meV) and with their homologous (K and Ag) for the sample with x=0.15 (Na content) in La1−x K x MnO3 system [35–37] (for example, ρ 0=0.0656 Ωcm, ρ 2=2.161×10−6 Ωcm K−2, ρ 4.5=0.1222×10−12 Ωcm K−4.5, and E
a =49.38 meV, in [36]) and La1−x Ag x MnO3 system [38] (ρ 0=0.130 Ωcm, ρ 2=8.39×10−6 Ωcm K−2, and ρ 4.5=1.59×10−12 Ωcm K−4.5).

The best fit parameters
$T^{\mathrm{mod}}_{C}$ and U 0 are also given in Table 6. The parameter U 0 may be viewed as an energy gap of the quasi-particles in the separated FM and PM phases. We found that U 0 is significantly smaller for x′=0 (U 0=121.55 meV) than that for x′=0.15 (U 0=149.44 meV). This difference may be related to the decrease of the DEC in Mn3+-O2−-Mn4+ framework, which makes the x′=0.15 sample more resistive as compared with the others.

As a result,
$T^{\mathrm{mod}}_{C}$ is close to the T
P (the M-I transition point); see Table 6. According to work in [39], in the polycrystalline samples, the effects of the grain boundaries on the variation of conductivity are much more pronounced. In particular, in samples with sufficiently small grain size no peak is seen on ρ(T) near T
C , but only a broadened maximum at T
P <T
C appears. In relatively good polycrystalline samples with large grain size, ρ(T) exhibits a sharp maximum at T
P which is near of T
C . In most cases, the contribution of grain boundaries effects was strongly emphasized. Let us note that the theoretical model based on a percolation approach predicts the appearance of a broad maximum on the ρ(T) curve at T<T
C and as a result,
$T_{C}^{\mathrm{mod}}$ is very close to T
P .

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para:
Our results show that the Na content (x′) in the synthesized manganite phases are significantly lower than the nominal values (x) in samples with nominal compositions La0.67Ba0.33−x Na x MnO3 (0≤x≤0.33). The manganite phase exhibits a rhombohedral (
$R\bar{3}c$ ) symmetry and a ferromagnetic/metallic–paramagnetic/insulator transitions. Structural parameters as well as variation of T
C and T
P with Na content are very close to those in [2] and [5], which gives a clear evidence that their nominal chemical formula of manganites is not close to the real composition achieved in their work and Na losses should be properly taken into account in order to explain the physical properties. The temperature dependence of the resistivity of our samples has been explained using the phenomenological percolation model, which is based on the phase segregation of FMM clusters and PMI regions. According to this model, we found that the x′=0.15 Na content is more resistive as compared with the others samples. All our results were usually attributed to the DE coupling, the variation of Mn3+/Mn4+ ratio, the average ionic radius of A-site and the bandwidth of e
g orbitals.
